title: Ivan Softa
text:
Ivan Softa (31 July 1906 – 1945) was a <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n writer and poet. He was often compared to <a href="Maxim%20Gorky">Maxim Gorky</a> because his first novel "Na cesti" is known as one of the best Croatian <a href="social%20realism">social realism</a> books.
Born in Smokinje near <a href="%C5%A0iroki%20Brijeg">Široki Brijeg</a> in 1906, he attended elementary school in <a href="Rasno%2C%20%C5%A0iroki%20Brijeg">Rasno</a>. Due to poverty he emigrated to <a href="Slavonia">Slavonia</a> and later moved to <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a> in 1934. Unemployment and uncertainty inspired him to write his first novel - "Na cesti" ("On the Road"), which gained success within Croatian literary critic, especially due to social dimension of the novel and influence of <a href="social%20realism">social realism</a>.
Except social themes, his works include motives of <a href="Herzegovina">Herzegovina</a>, his birth region, and its <a href="tradition">tradition</a> and <a href="folklore">folklore</a> ("Dani jada i glada").
His works were target of censorship during Yugoslav Communist regime.
